posts.name: Michael Barr
posts.cooked: In an elimination match a few days ago we accidentally ran an auto that ran us into the field wall. This caused our PD loop to run our 6 drive falcons at full voltage into the wall for about 10 seconds. After this, 4 of them failed. What is the best way to test whether or not we are doing damage to a falcon in code? Aren’t falcons supposed to have built in protections that prevent this from happening?

link_counts.title: Match 2 - Central Valley Regional 2023 - The Blue Alliance

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
What was the failure mode?

Aa falcon can run for 40 or 50 seconds at 60 amps before hitting thermal shutdown, which your breakers cannot come close to handling. Even after that, the falcon is fine.

6 falcons, stalled, should have been popping their breakers and maybe even the main breaker.  If you had them current limited to 40 amps so the breakers didnt go, 10 seconds wouldnt hurt them at all.

Something in the math doesnt make sense.

posts.name: Ian2
posts.cooked:
(This sounds like 1148 from our alliance at CVR this weekend. I was there helping to debug with one of the CSAs, too.)

The failure mode seems to be on the motor controller side of the Falcon, oddly without displaying failure codes on the LEDs. We didn’t check the fault status on Phoenix Tuner at the time, though I’d suggest y’all check that (including attempting to clear sticky faults) back at your lab. The motors show up in Phoenix Tuner and seem to be getting CAN data from the Rio. When the robot enables they go from blink orange to solid orange. However, when they should be driven based on id they stay solid orange.

On one side they had Falcon 500 motors with id 3, 4, 5, which all died to this failure mode. We swapped in new motors id 3 and later 4, verifying that the old 3 and 4 were not powered. The CAN chain happened to be in this order from the Rio, with the rest of the bot behind id 5. When only the new id 3 was in, the same code would spin motor 3 while driving (blink green leds) while motors 4 and 5 were not turning. Later new motors 3 and 4 would spin while motor 5 was still not spinning (solid orange leds).

Our discussion at the time is that their code sets all the motors individually, no leader-follower arrangements, though I don’t know if that’s for sure.

It’s odd. I’m not sure what this failure mode is and would appreciate some more informed advice. We (5026) have had all-Falcon bots for several seasons without experiencing this type of control failure.

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: This. Falcons are pretty hard to break, especially given the scenario you discribed. Really curious to see what happened.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked: Can’t comment much on the hardware side, but you should consider implementing stall detection in software to avoid such problem.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Tom_Line:

Aa falcon can run for 40 or 50 seconds at 60 amps before hitting thermal shutdown, which your breakers cannot come close to handling.

It’s quite possible for the breakers to sustain 60 amps for a minute, particularly with the Rev 40 amp breakers.

posts.name: Michael Barr
posts.cooked:
The breakers didn’t break

One of them wouldn’t turn on afterwards, one gave the hardware issue light and wouldn’t turn, and one didn’t and wouldn’t turn. I don’t remember what happened to the fourth, but we removed all the falcons from our robot. I don’t trust those little devils.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: If for some reason you feel you need to open up the Falcon V3 motors we wrote a teardown guide here: 4.9.4 Falcon 500 Fixes :: FRC Zero and it shows how to do it, what tools are needed, etc. If you figure out what went wrong I’ll probably add it to the list of potential issues for the Falcons

posts.name: Scott W
posts.cooked: Do you happen to know if that graph shows stator current or input current?  It doesn’t seem to say on the VEX motor data page.  I’m assuming stator.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: Thanks Joe!  You’re right of course.
